passages.text: USA | Equity Strategy
JEF's Performance Scorecard—The Good, The Bad, & The Ugly in August

The good was the strong showing by Small caps, with the size segment beating Large by 504bps. This put an end to Small's losing streak, at least for now, thanks to the potential of Fed easing, lower borrowing costs, and better earnings. The bad was lower cap, lower quality, non- earners drove performance with names \(Size QuintileR2R2GR2VQ1 (High)32.235.630.0Q237.436.233.8Q339.948.435.6Q441.840.842.6Q5 (Low)52.860.549.0ROE QuintileR2R2GR2V1 (Highest)33.933.328.7227.333.123.4333.142.031.8441.239.142.25 (Lowest)51.749.461.2Sales GrowthR2R2GR2VQ1 (Fastest)43.549.236.3Q229.533.231.1Q331.834.125.5Q429.130.730.0Q5 (Slowest)44.347.442.8No Sales39.429.267.0ValuationsR2R2GR2VQ1 (Lowest)35.441.531.7Q235.033.335.6Q327.836.329.9Q428.727.422.7Q5 (Highest)33.539.825.6Non52.450.954.2CohortR2R2GR2VCyclicals40.246.734.8Secular Growth33.129.443.2Bond Proxies17.718.617.4Benchmark35.137.532.6
Source: FactSet; FTSE Russell, Jefferies
Only Large Value beating since 4/8
Source: FactSet; Lipper Analytical Services; FTSE Russell, Jefferies

The summer slow down never happened with headlines hitting fast and furious just about every day. The bottom line is that lower Fed Funds are coming, borrowing costs are already down, and the earnings season was strong. All of this resulted in a very big win for the smallest of the small and the Russell 2000, leaving behind large as well as mid. A number of items to point out:

It was the best August for the R2000 since 2000, and the month had the feel like it was 2000, as retail- oriented stocks boosted performance along with lower quality and the smallest names. This came despite outflows into small- cap ETFs with \(11.4B coming out since the market low. From the low, the R2000 has jumped 35.1% vs. 30.7% for the R1000 and 29% for the RMID. The big winner has been micro caps, as the Russell benchmark returned a cool \(9.3\%\) in August, \(47\%\) since the low, and \(10.3\%\) YTD. To put the rally from the low into perspective, the gain for small is better than the average return 6- months after a Bear market ends, but the decline was also worse. The rebound is much better than "normal" for large, but basically in line for mid. It was a Value month with the R2V and RMV topping their Growth counterparts, but since the bottom, Growth has outperformed due to their Bond Proxy exposure. Two interesting notes: RMG is best performing index in the FTSE Russell family, while R25V is ahead of the R25G YTD. The better way to look at style is through our cohorts, and we find the Cyclicals chugging along and winning over all three time frames. This cohort was \(+7.6\%\) in August, \(40.2\%\) from the low, and \(10\%\) YTD, while Secular Growth returned \(6.8\%\) \(33.1\%\) and \(2.4\%\) respectively. As one would expect with the RUT jumping from the low, the Bond Proxies are behind at \(17.7\%\)
Chart 1 - Micro caps \(+10\%\) on the year, best August for RUT since '00
Source: FactSet; FTSE Russell; Jefferies
Chart 2 - It was a Value month but from the low, better for Growth along with so far this year
Source: FactSet; FTSE Russell; Jefferies
Chart 3 - Better way to look at performance, cohorts, Cyclicals \(+40\) since low and \(10\%\) YTD
Source: FactSet; FTSE Russell; Jefferies
Chart 4 - Bounce over last five months has been better than average for small and large
Source: Center for Research in Security Prices (CRSP), The University of Chicago Booth School of Business; Jefferies

As highlighted on the cover, lower- cap and lity have been driving performance since the bottom and have caused lots of headaches for active managers. However, this is not too dissimilar to previous periods, but the bad news for active is that this could last longer, especially if we start to see inflows to small- cap ETFs. We looked at low ROE outperformance cycles along with the factor coming out of Bear markets. Some points:

Since '90, we have seen 9 periods of low ROE beating the highest by a wide margin, with the gap standing at \(17.8\%\) since April 9. We are now up to just over 5 months of low ROE beating, but in these cycles the time frame varies between 3 months and 27. The underperformance is below the average and median, as of now. Coming out of Bear markets, low ROE tends to lead the way. The gain of \(51.7\%\) over the last 5 months is essentially in line with the average gain by the lowest ROE names after a Bear market has ended with the highest ROE also in line. These stocks are now trading at 3.8x sales, well above average, and twice as expensive as the highest ROE names. Flows have not played a role in the gain by lower ROE and one thing we fear is that whenif inflows do pick up, the rally by lower quality continues. We think investors need to add torque and beta to their portfolios to help contend with this rally.
Table 1 - The average low-quality cycle lasts over one year
Average Median Source: FactSet; FTSE Russell, Jefferies
Table 2 - Performance has been in line with what it tends to be over the subsequent 6-months after a Bear market

Chart 6 - Lowest ROE quintile trades at 3.8x sales. 2x that of the highest
Source: FactSet, FTSE Russell, Jefferies

Since the market bottomed, we have seen active REALLY struggle vs. their indexes, with only Large Value beating. It has been rough for Mid and Small Growth, along with Small Core trailing by \(5.2\%\) . We looked at the last five big underperformance periods for active across small- caps, and a few points:

Small Core is lagging the RUT by \(5.2\%\) with \(11\%\) of funds ahead, which is now worst since the five months after the election of '20. For Small Growth, with just \(16\%\) beating and the average fund is behind by \(5.6\%\) , this too is the toughest stretch since the election of '20. Value managers have fared better, as they are behind by \(1.2\%\) since the low, with \(39\%\) beating. The underperformance since 4/8 has severely impacted the YTD numbers, with \(24\%\) of managers ahead in Core, \(28\%\) in Growth, and \(33\%\) in Value. It has been the worst of times for Mid Growth, and things have only marginally gotten better post- rebalancing. Managers are lagging by over 700bps since the low, \(6.7\%\) YTD, and \(14\%\) over the last 12 months. Mid Value had a better August with \(93\%\) of the funds ahead and that closed the underperformance gap to \(1.4\%\) YTD. As for Core, over \(60\%\) beat during the month but the average fund trails by \(3.4\%\) YTD. Large Value managers have not faced the same challenges since the bottom as the other 8 categories with these investors ahead by \(1.4\%\) and topping the R1V by \(0.5\%\) YTD. Large Growth had a tough time in August; now \(33.5\%\) are ahead with the average fund lagging by \(0.7\%\) . The average Large Core fund slipped by \(0.4\%\) vs. the R1000 in August and now \(35\%\) are ahead YTD, but behind by just \(1.1\%\) . Even though we were in the midst of the reporting season and VOL fell, pair- wise correlations rose, which creates another headwind for active managers.
Table 3 - Only Large Value is beating their index since bounce off the market bottom % of managers beating index
PeriodAll ManagersSmall CoreSmall GrowthSmall ValueMid CoreMid GrowthMid ValueLarge CoreLarge GrowthLarge ValueAugust34281927604093282942Since April 8th24111639251639371953YTD2824283316832353455

Source: FactSet; Lipper Analytical Services; FTSE Russell, Jefferies
Chart 7 - Pair-wise correlations have stayed high despite VOL falling
Source: FactSet; FTSE Russell, Jefferies
With small firmly beating large, no new underperformance records but still a number of points to make:

The R1 and the R1G are the most concentrated ever, with the Top 10 weighing \(36.1\%\) and \(62.1\%\) , respectively. Given small's stellar showing in August, the Top- 5 names in the S&P 500 are now "only" \(5.1x\) as large as the entire RUT with these stocks trading at \(8.5x\) sales vs. \(2x\) for small caps. The R2 as a \(\%\) of the R3 based on market cap is off of its low but still stands at \(4.7\%\) . The rolling 10- year relative performance is off its recent low, going back to '35; as it stands at \(6.4\%\) vs. \(7.3\%\) one- month ago. The Jefferies Sweet 16 was up on average less than \(4\%\) in August and with solid earnings and revenue, the PTS slipped again to \(8.5x\) vs. about \(2x\) for the Russell 2000. Looking at a combination of '24 and '25 earnings and sales, our Sweet 16 makes up \(22\%\) of the total S&P 500 pie, yet these stocks weigh in at \(39\%\) of the S&P 500, now overweight by over \(17\%\) .
Chart 8 - The rolling 10-year return is off of its low...
Source: Center for Research in Security Prices (CRSP), The University of Chicago Booth School of Business Jefferies
Chart 9 - ...Along with the R2 as a \(\%\) of the R3
Source: FactSet; FTSE Russell, Jefferies
Chart 10 - The Top-5 names in S&P 500 are "only" \(5.1x\) the size of the RUT
Source: FactSet; FTSE Russell, Jefferies
Chart 11 - The PTS ratio for our Sweet 16 stands at \(8.5x\) vs. \(2.0x\) for RUT
Source: FactSet; Standard & Poors, Jefferies
Chart 12 - R1 and R1G most-concentrated ever
Source: FactSet; FTSE Russell, Jefferies
Chart 13 - Our Sweet 16's weight is \(17\%\) bigger than their earnings & sales contribution
Source: FactSet; Standard & Poors, Jefferies

We have been dealt a decent disappointment with now the Street expecting Q3 earnings growth to once again favor the large caps. However, we think some of this was an adjustment of such strong growth by small caps in Q2 and little incentive to move up full year '25, so analysts cut Q3 and Q4 aggressively down cap. Some points:

As we highlighted in our recent Earnings Note, the gap between actual and consensus has been one of the widest across small caps in recent history. Earnings were forecasted to be lower by \(4\%\) coming into the reporting season and instead, small's growth rate hit almost \(6\%\) . The trend in '25 has also been good with minor increases in the growth rate for small and mid, while large has moved from \(9.1\%\) to \(9.7\%\) over the month of August. One big fly in the ointment: Given what we think is a more cautious outlook for full year earnings for small and mid, we now see large once again delivering better growth in the Q3 reporting season. If this holds true, it would mark the 13th straight quarter of better earnings for large than small and the losing streak for mid would be 12. The '25 earnings growth rate for large caps of \(9.7\%\) does not tell the entire story. Our Sweet 16 is now expected to post earnings growth of over \(20\%\) in '25 vs. \(17\%\) at the end of June. As for the 'Rest of the S&P 500', earnings are looking to rise \(5.8\%\) when the estimated growth rate was \(5.1\%\) on June 30. With the potential for a better economic backdrop, earnings growth in '26 is expected to rebound sharply for small caps at \(19\%\) thanks to Fin's, Comm Services (?), and Industrials. This is a bump up from last month. As for mid, earnings are expected to rise \(16.2\%\) not much of a change from this time last month. As for large, earnings are looking to rise \(12\%\) in '26 with the breakout being \(15.4\%\) for our Sweet 16 and \(10.6\%\) for the 'Rest of the S&P 500'.
Table 5 - A disappointment, Q3 is now expected to go to the large caps, again in terms of earnings growth Earnings Growth (in %)
Table 6 - A few volatile sectors are expected to drive '26 earnings growth

Given the nice bounce by small and Value, absolute and relative valuations rose. Several points:

The forward P/E rose to \(20.1x\) from \(19.3x\) and given this, our absolute valuation model moved to the 75th percentile. As for the R1000, its P/E is still at \(25.9x\) . Given the outperformance for small vs. large, our relative model ticked up to the 7th percentile. With Value beating Growth, our relative valuation model moved to Q2 from Q1, and is in the 22nd percentile. Its P/E stands at \(16.7x\) vs. \(23.4x\) for the R2G.
Chart 16 - The RUT's P/E is above 20x...
Note: Based on Jefferies estimates as of August 31. Source: FactSet; FTSE Russell, Jefferies
Chart 17 - ...While R2V trades at 16.7x vs. 23.4x for R2G
Note: Based on Jefferies estimates as of August 31. Source: FactSet; FTSE Russell, Jefferies
Chart 18 - Small & Value got slightly more expensive on relative basis in August
Source: FactSet; FTSE Russell, Jefferies
With the potential for Fed cuts and borrowing costs already falling, we really like the macro backdrop for small. Some numbers:
Rates fell in anticipation of the Fed easing as early as September with the 2- year yield down more than the 10- year. This put the shape of the curve at 61bps and the widest in 3 years.
The dollar—has taken a back seat to rates, but the trade- weighted dollar fell \(2.2\%\) in August and is down close to \(10\%\) YTD. This is very supportive for small caps.

High- Yield Spreads—Back below \(3\%\) after hitting \(4.5\%\) after "Liberation Day", and down another 16bps on the month. Also, important is that the YTM for HY is down to \(7\%\) and off 65bps since the start of the year.
Volatility—The VIX index slipped \(8\%\) in August and at 15, it is well below its long- term average.

Our DCF- based price target of \(\) 60\(implies a 26x multiple of our CY26 revenue estimate. Upside risks include 1) faster - than - expected monetization of Artificial Intelligence Platform (AIP); 2) sustained commercial momentum across Foundry and AIP; and 3) potential for PLTR to successfully expand further mass market and grow its customer count.
(Article 3(1)e and Article 7 of MAR) Recommendation Published Recommendation Distributed

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) is \(20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period. NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations. Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to

have a \(15\%\) stop loss, and the remainder will have a \(20\%\) stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
